<item>
	<title>This week in Toronto: Sgt. Pepper’s dance group and The Headless Woman</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">1318067d-5d1c-4150-8bf4-604e34e057d2</guid>
	<author></author>
	<pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 08:00:00 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/headless_woman.jpg"/><br/>Our curated guide to the week’s best offerings also includes chanteuse and former French first lady Carla Bruni, a dance legend passing the baton and more. </description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/headless_woman.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>This week in Toronto: Sgt. Pepper’s dance group and The Headless Woman</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/headless_woman.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Maria Onetto, left, and Ines Efron in The Headless Woman.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">TIFF</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/whang_od_oggay.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>This week in Toronto: Sgt. Pepper’s dance group and The Headless Woman</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/whang_od_oggay.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Whang-od Oggay, who is believed to be 101 years old, is passing on the art of hand-tapped tattoos that she learned from her father to her grandniece in Buscalan in the Philippines. She is one of the subjects of Skindigenous, a series about Indigenous tattooing.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">NISH MEDIA</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/cat_on_a_hot.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>This week in Toronto: Sgt. Pepper’s dance group and The Headless Woman</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/cat_on_a_hot.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Jack O'Connell and Sienna Miller are Brick and Maggie in the National Theatre version of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, coming to Toronto Cineplex screens.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">JOHAN PERSSON</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner"></media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/peggy_2008.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>This week in Toronto: Sgt. Pepper’s dance group and The Headless Woman</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/peggy_2008.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Legendary dancer and choreographer Peggy Baker takes to the stage again in unmoored, part of the program Map by Years at the Theatre Centre.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">RICHARD LAUTENS</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">TORONTO STAR FILE PHOTO</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/pepperland.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>This week in Toronto: Sgt. Pepper’s dance group and The Headless Woman</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/this-week-in-toronto-sgt-peppers-dance-group-and-the-headless-woman/pepperland.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>The Mark Morris Dance Group in  Pepperland, a tribute to the Beatles album Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, at the Sony Centre on Feb. 24.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">GARETH JONES</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner"></media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>Nobody nose who this movie star is — oh, OK, everybody nose: Stargazing</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2018/02/18/nobody-nose-who-this-movie-star-is-oh-ok-everybody-nose-stargazing.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">2b4f1cbf-6c33-49b4-8dbd-975dd7d6195c</guid>
	<author>Garnet Fraser - Toronto Star</author>
	<pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 07:00:00 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/nobody-nose-who-this-movie-star-is-oh-ok-everybody-nose-stargazing/driver.jpg"/><br/>This week: smart-dressed gents are seen in hats. Or taut, rock-hard abs like Justin Bieber. Whichever.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/nobody-nose-who-this-movie-star-is-oh-ok-everybody-nose-stargazing/driver.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Nobody nose who this movie star is — oh, OK, everybody nose: Stargazing</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/18/nobody-nose-who-this-movie-star-is-oh-ok-everybody-nose-stargazing/driver.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>We don’t know much about this movie now filming, but if you looked at the face and said “it stars Adam Driver,” congratulations! (Honourable mention to those who guessed Adrien Brody.)</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">SARA</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">backgrid photo</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>Twitter trolls lie about being attacked by Black people while going to see Black Panther</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2018/02/17/twitter-trolls-lie-about-being-attacked-by-black-people-while-going-to-see-black-panther.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">268d1a22-b185-4bec-868f-5c71a422b5c6</guid>
	<author>Jaclyn Cosgrove - Los Angeles Times,Greg Braxton</author>
	<pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 19:01:17 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/17/twitter-trolls-lie-about-being-attacked-by-black-people-while-going-to-see-black-panther/black_panther.jpg"/><br/>“It’s very unfortunate that a film that is poised to become a cultural icon is being marred by this fake news,” said Darnell Hunt, dean of social sciences at the University of California, Los Angeles.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/17/twitter-trolls-lie-about-being-attacked-by-black-people-while-going-to-see-black-panther/black_panther.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Twitter trolls lie about being attacked by Black people while going to see Black Panther</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/17/twitter-trolls-lie-about-being-attacked-by-black-people-while-going-to-see-black-panther/black_panther.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>From left, Danai Gurira, Lupita Nyong'o and Florence Kasumba in a scene from "Black Panther." Over the past few days, users have posted false claims that they were attacked by Black people while going to see the movie.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">Matt Kennedy</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">Disney/Marvel Studios via The Associated Press</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>Tabloids: Weep for Jennifer Aniston, one more time (and Khloe Kardashian too)</title>

	<pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 17:00:00 EST</pubDate>

Well, except Britney Spears, with her 23-year-old model boyfriend and all. </description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/17/tabloids-weep-for-jennifer-aniston-one-more-time-and-khloe-kardashian-too/lifestyle_jpg.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Tabloids: Weep for Jennifer Aniston, one more time (and Khloe Kardashian too)</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/17/tabloids-weep-for-jennifer-aniston-one-more-time-and-khloe-kardashian-too/lifestyle_jpg.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Of human blondage.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>

</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>Actors Rebecca Gayheart, Eric Dane file for divorce after 14 years of marriage</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2018/02/17/actors-rebecca-gayheart-eric-dane-file-for-divorce-after-14-years-of-marriage.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">1c8ba0d7-27fc-46fb-8aba-6eb1af002dcd</guid>
	<author>Bryan Alexander - USA Today</author>
	<pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 10:53:48 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/television/2018/02/17/actors-rebecca-gayheart-eric-dane-file-for-divorce-after-14-years-of-marriage/comp_dane_gayheart.jpg"/><br/>Gayheart, 46, filed the papers on Friday, citing irreconcilable differences with Dane, 45, better known as Grey’s “McSteamy” Dr. Mark Sloan.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/television/2018/02/17/actors-rebecca-gayheart-eric-dane-file-for-divorce-after-14-years-of-marriage/comp_dane_gayheart.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Actors Rebecca Gayheart, Eric Dane file for divorce after 14 years of marriage</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/television/2018/02/17/actors-rebecca-gayheart-eric-dane-file-for-divorce-after-14-years-of-marriage/comp_dane_gayheart.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Rebecca Gayheart, left, is shown Jan. 7, 2018. Eric Dane, right, is shown in a handout photo on the set of The Last Ship.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">Frazer Harrison</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">GETTY IMAGES and TNT</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>

<item>
	<title>Life after death for America’s TV dad</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2018/02/17/life-after-death-for-americas-tv-dad.html</link>

	<author>Yvonne Villarreal - Los Angeles Times</author>
	<pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 06:00:00 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/television/2018/02/17/life-after-death-for-americas-tv-dad/milo_as_jack.jpg"/><br/>As flawed-but-nearly-perfect Jack Pearson on This Is Us, Milo Ventimiglia has joined the roster of great TV patriarchs.</description>

	<media:description>Milo Ventimiglia has become a pop-culture folk hero as Jack Pearson in This Is Us.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">NBC</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">RON BATZDORFF</media:credit>

</item>
<item>
	<title>Rock’s decline has stars taking their final bow </title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/opinion/2018/02/17/rocks-decline-has-stars-taking-their-final-bow.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">44267972-4771-47a3-a66d-9ea8fc3ef9db</guid>
	<author>Joel Rubinoff - Torstar News Service</author>
	<pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 06:00:00 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/music/opinion/2018/02/17/rocks-decline-has-stars-taking-their-final-bow/elton_john.jpg"/><br/>Sixty years after rock ‘n’ roll stormed the barricades, its aging progenitors find themselves shut out of the cultural spotlight as hip hop takes the lead.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/music/opinion/2018/02/17/rocks-decline-has-stars-taking-their-final-bow/elton_john.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Rock’s decline has stars taking their final bow </media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/music/opinion/2018/02/17/rocks-decline-has-stars-taking-their-final-bow/elton_john.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Elton John, at 70, wants to spend more time with his kids.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">Evan Agostini</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">Invision/AP</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>As a concert-going audience, we can do better</title>

</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>Soulpepper loses $375,000 from grant over Schultz sexual harassment allegations</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2018/02/16/soulpepper-loses-promised-375000-grant-over-schultz-sexual-harassment-allegations.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">c323d927-3954-4654-9959-a40234c6849a</guid>
	<author>Brennan Doherty - Staff Reporter</author>
	<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 22:03:48 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/16/soulpepper-loses-promised-375000-grant-over-schultz-sexual-harassment-allegations/albert_schultz.jpg"/><br/>The Canada Council for the Arts had approved a $559,500 grant last fall before rescinding it following sexual harassment allegations against founding artistic director Albert Schultz. Soulpepper will still be given a $184,500 grant for the year.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/16/soulpepper-loses-promised-375000-grant-over-schultz-sexual-harassment-allegations/albert_schultz.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Soulpepper loses $375,000 from grant over Schultz sexual harassment allegations</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/2018/02/16/soulpepper-loses-promised-375000-grant-over-schultz-sexual-harassment-allegations/albert_schultz.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Former Soulepper artistic director and founder Albert Schultz was accused by four women of sexual harassment in January.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">Chris Young</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>Kim Coates makes a remarkable return to the stage as Rooster Byron in Jerusalem</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/kim-coates-makes-a-remarkable-return-to-the-stage-as-rooster-byron-in-jerusalem.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">851d99e3-0879-4872-82ca-c5031dace94a</guid>
	<author>Carly Maga - Theatre Critic</author>
	<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 19:24:31 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/kim-coates-makes-a-remarkable-return-to-the-stage-as-rooster-byron-in-jerusalem/kim_coates.jpg"/><br/>Some references in Jez Butterworth's play about the state of England didn't register, but its magical realism fits well on the otherworldly set created inside Toronto’s Streetcar Crowsnest.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/kim-coates-makes-a-remarkable-return-to-the-stage-as-rooster-byron-in-jerusalem/kim_coates.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Kim Coates makes a remarkable return to the stage as Rooster Byron in Jerusalem</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/kim-coates-makes-a-remarkable-return-to-the-stage-as-rooster-byron-in-jerusalem/kim_coates.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Kim Coates as Rooster Byron, who goes from oddball eccentric with a drug and drinking problem to something more mysterious, magical and frightening in Jez Butterworth's Jerusalem.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">DAHLIA KATZ</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">041815b8-b08c-45a3-91e6-49ff81844bbe</guid>
	<author>Murray Whyte - Visual Arts Critic</author>
	<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 18:49:41 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/st_anthon.jpg"/><br/>Such a show would have been ‘unthinkable’ while Mitchell and Riopelle were alive, but their union shaped their painting in ways you can’t deny, writes Murray Whyte.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/st_anthon.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/st_anthon.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Joan Mitchell's "Untitled" 1955, left,  hanging next to Jean-Paul Riopelle's Saint-Anthon, 1954, at the Art Gallery of Ontario. The artists' long-time relationship influenced their work in both subtle and overt ways, a new show suggests.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">ANDREW FRANCIS WALLACE</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">TORONTO STAR</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/canada.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/canada.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>A triptych from Joan Mitchell's "Canada" series (1975) at the AGO. Dominated by a towering, muddy triptych of blues, browns and blacks, the paintings seem to signal their union slowly dwindling toward its end.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">ANDREW FRANCIS WALLACE</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">TORONTO STAR</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/whale.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/whale.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Jean-Paul Riopelle's "From the Great Whale"  (left) and "Homage to Grey Owl" (1970) at the AGO's "Mitchell/Riopelle."</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">Rene Johnston</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/gitksan.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/gitksan.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Jean-Paul Riopelle's Gitksan (1958) next to Joan Mitchell's "Untitled" (1958).</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">COURTESY ART GALLERY OF ONTARIO</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/marlin.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/marlin.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Joan Mitchell's Marlin, 1960.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">ANDREW FRANCIS WALLACE</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">TORONTO STAR</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/e1_riopelle_mitchell.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/e1_riopelle_mitchell.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle would have hated to have their paintings exhibited together, but “these two sensitive and extremely powerful personalities could not have evolved without being affected by the singular context of their relationship as it developed over the years,” writes curator Michel Martin.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">RENE JOHNSTON</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">TORONTO STAR</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/chicago_photo.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/chicago_photo.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Jean-Paul Riopelle and Joan Mitchell together in her hometown of Chicago in 1956. The couple had just begun their 25-year union.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">COURTESY ART GALLERY OF ONTARIO</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/rpjriopellemitchell04_jpg.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>An AGO exhibit compares the paintings of long-time couple Joan Mitchell and Jean-Paul Riopelle. They would have hated that</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/visualarts/2018/02/16/an-ago-exhibit-compares-the-paintings-of-long-time-couple-joan-mitchell-and-jean-paul-riopelle-they-would-have-hated-that/rpjriopellemitchell04_jpg.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Jean-Paul Riopelle's 'Iceberg No. 3' (1977) (left) and 'The Water Line' (1977) (right). Back in Canada, Riopelle reconnected with the land.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">Rene Johnston</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>

<item>
	<title>Opera Atelier’s Harmonia Sacra seamlessly blends voice and dance in its single Toronto performance</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/opera-ateliers-harmonia-sacra-seamlessly-blends-voice-and-dance-in-its-single-toronto-performance.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">ad6fbbc4-b9f8-4fe1-b834-400bddc8356b</guid>
	<author>John Terauds - Special to the Star</author>
	<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 15:34:17 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/opera-ateliers-harmonia-sacra-seamlessly-blends-voice-and-dance-in-its-single-toronto-performance/harmonia_sacra.jpg"/><br/>The show was first presented at the Palace of Versailles outside Paris. Now it was Toronto’s turn to see a show worthy of any royal palace in the world.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/opera-ateliers-harmonia-sacra-seamlessly-blends-voice-and-dance-in-its-single-toronto-performance/harmonia_sacra.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Opera Atelier’s Harmonia Sacra seamlessly blends voice and dance in its single Toronto performance</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/opera-ateliers-harmonia-sacra-seamlessly-blends-voice-and-dance-in-its-single-toronto-performance/harmonia_sacra.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Artists of Atelier Ballet Juri Hiraoka, Tyler Gledhill and Jeannette Lajeunesse Zingg perform in Opera Atelier's Harmonia Sacra at the ROM.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">BRUCE ZINGER</media:credit>
</media:content><media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/opera-ateliers-harmonia-sacra-seamlessly-blends-voice-and-dance-in-its-single-toronto-performance/harmonia_sacra_2.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>Opera Atelier’s Harmonia Sacra seamlessly blends voice and dance in its single Toronto performance</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/opera-ateliers-harmonia-sacra-seamlessly-blends-voice-and-dance-in-its-single-toronto-performance/harmonia_sacra_2.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Canadian soprano Mireille Asselin, seen with American baritone Jesse Blumberg and members of the Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra, is a treasure, writes John Terauds.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">BRUCE ZINGER</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
<item>
	<title>In Toronto production of King Charles III the acting is of royal calibre, the design not so much</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/in-toronto-production-of-king-charles-iii-the-acting-is-of-royal-calibre-the-design-not-so-much.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">27568931-0fec-4926-ac69-09284198cad9</guid>
	<author>Karen Fricker - Theatre Critic</author>
	<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 14:16:18 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/in-toronto-production-of-king-charles-iii-the-acting-is-of-royal-calibre-the-design-not-so-much/king_charles_iii.jpg"/><br/>Play now on at CAA Theatre doesn’t look as lavish as one would hope, but fine performances and a well-paced production do justice to Mike Bartlett’s script.</description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/in-toronto-production-of-king-charles-iii-the-acting-is-of-royal-calibre-the-design-not-so-much/king_charles_iii.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>In Toronto production of King Charles III the acting is of royal calibre, the design not so much</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/stage/review/2018/02/16/in-toronto-production-of-king-charles-iii-the-acting-is-of-royal-calibre-the-design-not-so-much/king_charles_iii.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>In King Charles III, the British prime minister (Gray Powell, right) wants to curtail mainstream and social media, but Charles (David Schurmann, centre) defends the freedom of the press, egged on by the Conservative leader of the opposition (Patrick Galligan).</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">CYLLA VON TIEDEMANN</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>

<item>
	<title>Hedley openers leave tour, CBC drops band from radio, streaming amid sexual misconduct allegations </title>

<item>
	<title>We'll never know why Kim Cattrall called out Sarah Jessica Parker, but we know it’s sad</title>
	<link>https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/opinion/2018/02/16/well-never-know-why-kim-cattrall-called-out-sarah-jessica-parker-but-we-know-its-sad.html</link>
	<guid isPermaLink="false">221f92d6-c1d0-4d75-9d44-e7d5e068a723</guid>
	<author>Shinan Govani - Star Columnist</author>
	<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 10:00:00 EST</pubDate>
	<description><img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/opinion/2018/02/16/well-never-know-why-kim-cattrall-called-out-sarah-jessica-parker-but-we-know-its-sad/sex_and_the_city_cast.jpg"/><br/>Sex and the City centred on the joys of female friendship. This dark turn in real life between its two stars can’t help but leave a crease on its legacy, writes Shinan Govani. </description>
<media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/opinion/2018/02/16/well-never-know-why-kim-cattrall-called-out-sarah-jessica-parker-but-we-know-its-sad/sex_and_the_city_cast.jpg" medium="image">
	<media:title>We'll never know why Kim Cattrall called out Sarah Jessica Parker, but we know it’s sad</media:title>
	<media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/opinion/2018/02/16/well-never-know-why-kim-cattrall-called-out-sarah-jessica-parker-but-we-know-its-sad/sex_and_the_city_cast.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	<media:description>Kim Cattrall, second from right, with her Sex and the City co-stars  Cynthia Nixon, Sarah Jessica Parker and Kristin Davis in 2008.</media:description>
	<media:credit role="author">PETER KRAMER</media:credit>
	<media:credit role="owner">THE ASSOCIATED PRESS FILE PHOTO</media:credit>
</media:content>
</item>
</channel></rss>
